awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT:  Developing an Efficient Computation Scheme for Modeling Low-Pressure Plasmas
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project is the significant reduction of low-pressure-plasma modeling time using innovative computation schemes.  Low-pressure plasmas are widely used for the manufacturing of semiconductor integrated circuits, displays, solar panels, thin film batteries, and coatings. The annual market of these industry segments exceeds $600 billion. Computer simulation is an essential approach to understanding the complex plasma characteristics and developing efficient plasma processing technologies. Unfortunately, current commercial plasma simulation software requires huge computational resources; it takes months to model the plasmas in practical scales. The lack of a practical tool for modeling low-pressure plasmas has resulted in improperly designed sources, leading to the inefficient processes used today. This PFI-TT project aims to develop new computation schemes for efficiently modeling certain plasmas at low pressures. These tools will allow the users to simulate plasmas of practical scales, using even desktop computers that generate feedback in 24 hours. This project will also train and broaden the participation of graduate and undergraduate students, and prepare them as future leaders in technology innovation and entrepreneurship.   

The proposed project combines an implicit algorithm of the motions of charged particles with an energy conservation scheme to eliminate the spatial and temporal constraints in the state-of-the-art explicit particle-in-cell/Monte Carlo collision algorithms. The key advantage of the implicit algorithm is that the high frequency oscillations of plasmas are damped in the time domain. The energy conservation scheme ensures that the total energy of the plasma is conserved and the self-heating due to a large grid spacing (i.e. significantly greater than the plasma Debye length) is eliminated. The new computation scheme is over 30 times faster than the state-of-the-art explicit particle-in-cell/Monte Carlo collision algorithms. The developed modeling tools also have the potential to address situations where a complete kinetic analysis is not yet available due to the high plasma density, such as high-power impulse magnetron sputtering and the plasma instabilities in magnetized discharges.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcome Report

Low-pressure plasmas are widely used for the manufacturing of semiconductor integrated circuits, displays, solar panels, thin film batteries, and coatings. The annual market of these industry segments exceeds $600 billion. Simulation is an essential approach to understanding complex plasma characteristics and developing novel plasma technologies. Unfortunately, the state-of-the-art explicit particle-in-cell/Monte Carlo collision algorithms used for simulating low-pressure plasma discharges require huge computational resources; it takes months to self-consistently model the plasmas in practical scales. This drawback becomes aggravated when a magnetic field is coupled with the plasma.

The major goal of this PFI-TT project is to develop an innovative computation scheme that allows users to efficiently model plasma even with desktop computers.

We first developed a plasma simulation code that combined an implicit algorithm with an energy conservation scheme to alleviate the spatial and temporal constraints in conventional particle-in-cell/Monte Carlo collision algorithms. The key advantage of the implicit algorithm is that the high-frequency oscillation of plasma is damped in the time domain. The energy conservation scheme ensures the conservation of the total energy of the plasma and the self-heating due to a large grid spacing (i.e., significantly greater than the plasma Debye length) can be eliminated. We subsequently simulated a variety of practical-scale plasma discharges using our code. These plasma discharges included sputtering magnetrons operating under DC and RF excitations, ion sources, and capacitively coupled plasma. This simulation results were in excellent agreement with experimental results and well-established benchmarks. Most importantly, the simulations were run on desktop computers and the simulation was much faster than the state-of-the-art commercial software based on the particle model. We then developed an online platform with a simple and intuitive interface, allowing users to build their own model and submit projects to a server computer or cloud computation facility. This approach provides users with great flexibility and saves costs, while effectively protecting our intellectual property.

In terms of broader impacts on society, this plasma simulation platform has been tested by users from industry and academic institutions for understanding plasma discharges and inventing new plasma sources, demonstrating efficient computation capability and accurate results on practically large scales. The simulation tool directly resulted in the development of a patented single beam plasma source that can greatly improve the crystallinity of thin films deposited at low temperatures. A company is interested in licensing this plasma simulation technology from Michigan State University. Two graduate students were trained through this project. The research has resulted in seven publications and multiple conference presentations.
